description: From Middle English absent, from Middle French absent, from Old French ausent, and their source, Latin absens, present participle of absum (“to be away from”), from ab (“away”) + sum (“to be”).

entries.meaning: (not comparable) Being away from a place; withdrawn from a place; not present; missing. [First attested around 1350 to 1470.]
(not comparable) Not existing; lacking. [First attested around 1350 to 1470.]
examples: The part was rudimental or absent.

entries.meaning: (comparable) Inattentive to what is passing; absent-minded; preoccupied. [First attested in the early 18th century.]
examples: For days Ailie had an absent eye and a sad face, and it so fell out that in all that time young Heriotside, who had scarce missed a day, was laid up with a broken arm and never came near her.

entries.meaning: (with definite article) Something absent, especially absent people collectively; those who were or are not there. [from 15th c.]
examples: The Applause he met with exceeds all belief of the Absent.

entries.meaning: (obsolete, Scotland) An absentee; a person who is not there. [15th–19th c.]
In the absence of; without; except. [First attested in the mid 20th century.]
examples: Absent taxes modern governments cannot function.

description: From Middle English absenten, from Old French absenter, from Late Latin absentāre (“keep away, be away”).

verbs.description: absent (third-person singular simple present absents, present participle absenting, simple past and past participle absented)

examples: Most of the men are retired, jobless, or have otherwise temporarily absented themselves from the workplace.

entries.meaning: (transitive, archaic) To keep (someone) away. [First attested around 1350 to 1470.]
(intransitive, obsolete) Stay away; withdraw. [Attested from around 1350 to 1470 until the late 18th century.]
